Institute of Low Temperature and Structure Research, Polish Academy of Sciences, P.O.Box 937, 50-950 Wroctaw, Poland Received 13 December 1995; revised 27 May 1996; accepted 29 May 1996 Abstract The effect of high temperature reduction (HTR) in hydrogen (up to 1180 K) on the microstructure of 9 wt.-% Pd/CeO2 catalyst was studied by HRTEM and XRD methods. Reduction of the catalyst at or above 973 K caused severe recrystallization of CeO2 and Pd with simultaneous strong interaction between the two components appearing as three phenomena: epitaxial growth of small Pd particles on CeO2 (most frequently with [lll]Pdll[lll]CeO2); decoration of large Pd particles with ordered CeO2 overlayer and expansion of the lattice parameter of Pd (by 2.1%). The origin of the Pd lattice expansion is discussed and diffusion of Ce species into the Pd lattice seems to be the most probable one. HTR caused also phase transformations in the ceria support. At 973 K and 1100 K, whole CeO2 was transformed into oxygen deficient CeOx phase exhibiting the same or similar structure but with expanded lattice parameter (by 2.8%). At 1180 K most ceria was transformed into hexagonal A-Ce203. The CeO~ phase appeared to be stable in hydrogen and in vacuum at room temperature, but upon exposure to air at room temperature it rapidly reoxidised to CeO2. Ce203 also reoxidised to CeO2 but much slower. Another consequence of HTR at or above 773 K was formation of pits in CeO2 crystallites, mainly on (112)-type crystal faces. The pits (1-10 nm) exhibited well defined walls parallel to CeO2 lattice fringes and they could possibly constitute nucleation sites for strongly bonded, epitaxial oriented Pd particles. High temperature reduction (HTR) of such catalysts in hydrogen (T>~ 773 K) induces enhanced interaction between metal and ceria modifying drastically the catalytic activity [1-10]. Several models were pro- posed to account for this phenomenon but conclusive explanation is still lacking. The most common interpretation assuming migration of partly reduced ceria onto the surface of metal particles has been proposed [4,8] based on chemisorp- tion and catalytic measurements. Extended high resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) studies summarised in a very recent review by Bernal et al. [11], showed that decoration of metal particles by partly reduced ceria does not occur in Rh/CeO2 [11,12] and Pt/CeO2 [13,14] catalysts reduced in hydrogen up to 773 K. Recently, decoration effects have been observed in Pd/CeO2 [15] and Rh/CeO2 [11] reduced in hydrogen at 873 K and 973 K, respectively. Alternatively, special epitaxial orientation of metal particles on crystalline ceria support, observed by HRTEM and microdiffraction methods for Rh [11,12,16], Pt [13,14] and Au [13] at 773 K is considered as possible cause of the SMSI effect. Finally, formation of intermetallic alloys or compounds of Me-Ce type reported for Pt [17] and Pd [15] at 1173 K and 873 K, respectively, should be taken into account. In a previous paper [15] we have shown that chloride from the metal precursor drastically modifies the microstructure of Pd/ceria catalyst upon HTR, due to the formation of stable cerium oxychloride (CeOC1), and stabilisa- tion of an oxygen deficient CeOx phase. In this work we report on extensive studies on microstructure characterisation (HRTEM, ED and XRD) of Pd/CeO2 catalyst prepared from a chloride free precursor -- Pd nitrate. We expanded also the range of reduction temperatures up to 1180 K to cover the conditions occurring in working TWC catalysts. The results may be of interest in view of recent attempts to use single metal Pd/ceria/alumina catalysts as TWC for automotive pollution control [ 18]. 2. Epitaxial orientation in Pd-CeO2 system Results obtained in this work (Fig. 9) clearly show that in Pd/CeO2 samples reduced in hydrogen at 973 K large number of Pd particles with sizes of 1 to 10 nm are epitaxial oriented with respect to CeO2 support. The orientation (Pd (111) lattice planes parallel to CeO2 (111) planes) is characteristic for CeO2 supported metals and has already been observed for Rh [11,12,16], Pt [13,14] and Au [13]. It should be stated, however, that in our case four Pd (111) lattice planes with expanded lattice parameter (4 × 0.229 nm = 0.916 nm) match three CeO2 (111) planes (3 × 0.312 nm= 0.936 nm) with misfit approx. 2%, which is much less than 6% for Rh [12]. It appears, that expansion of Pd lattice reduces the misfit between Pd and CeO2, however, as will be discussed later, the expansion is in our opinion caused also by incorporation of cerium into the Pd lattice (formation of Pd-Ce alloy). 4.2. Expansion of Pd lattice parameter Our SAED and XRD results indicate a 2.1% increase of Pd lattice parameter following reduction at 973 K for 20 h. Higher reduction temperature (up to 1180 K) or longer reduction time (45 h) did not result in further increase of the lattice 214 L. Kcp#iski, M. Wolcyrz /Applied Catalysis A: General 150 (1997) 197-220 expansion (cf. Tables 1 and 2). It may be understood if we assume that the lattice expansion is caused by Pd-Ce alloying. Then, 2.1% expansion corre- sponds roughly to the solubility limit of Ce in Pd [19,20]. The next phase in the Pd-Ce phase diagram close to Pd-Ce solid solution is a superstructure fcc phase PdvCe with roughly doubled Pd lattice parameter (0.795-0.812 nm) (high temperature modification) [20]. In fact our HRTEM results (Fig. 16) may indicate that such ordered phase forms at the surface of Pd particles. It appears also (Tables 1 and 2) that the 'expanded' Pd forms well distinguishable, single phase with average particle size of ca. 30 nm at 973 K and 1100 K, which suddenly increases to 55 nm at 1180 K. There is an interesting correlation between sudden growth of Pd average particle size and simultaneous structure transformation and recrystallization of the support: at 973 K to the 'expanded' CeO2 phase [15,21] and at 1180 K to a hexagonal Ce203 ([21], this work). Formation of intermetallic compounds or alloys during reduction with hydrogen was reported for powder catalysts Pd/CeO2 at 873 K [15] and Pt/CeO2 at 773 K [2] and 1173 K [17] and also for another metal/oxide systems at similar temperatures [22-29]. Recently, Alexandrou and Nix [30] showed by using various surface sensitive methods that CeOx overlayer on Pd (111) surface dissolved into the bulk of metal when heated in ultra high vacuum (UHV) at or above 770 K. The chemical reaction with the support (alloying) modifies the reactivity of supported palladium in benzene hydrogenation [15] and in carbonization [28,29]. Similar effects may be expected also for hydration reaction, since it is known that addition of solute element to Pd reduces the maximum solubility of hydrogen ([3-hydride) and reduces the cx-[3 miscibility gap [31]. In fact, lowering of the hydrogen absorption by alumina supported Pd due to high temperature reduction at 870 K has been observed [32]. An important question concems the origin of the expansion of Pd lattice parameter observed in this experiment. Is it caused by alloying with Ce or by any other reason, e.g.,. B-hydride formation? We exclude the latter possibility because of the following reasons. It is known that [3-Pd hydride is stable under normal hydrogen pressure only up to 430 K [33] and therefore it can be formed in our experiments only during cooling in hydrogen. There is thus no reason, why it should form in samples reduced at 973 K and not in those reduced at 773 and 573 K. Moreover, our experiments with the samples cooled in vacuum and especially with Pd black (Table 1) clearly exclude this possibility. The second argument against hydride is its instability in the absence of hydrogen. EXAFS data showed that [3-Pd hydride formed in Pd/C and Pd/A1203 catalysts decomposed very quickly in pure Ar already at room temperature [34]. In our work we exposed the reduced samples to air before XRD and TEM analysis, so decomposition of eventual hydride would be even faster than in Ar. Nevertheless, we observed the 'expanded' Pd phase in samples stored in air for several days (Fig. 3) or even several months [15]. L. Kcpifiski, M. We can exclude the other contaminants as possible solute in Pd in view of our EDS results, Fig. 1. The Pd-O solid solution characterised by Pd lattice expansion was observed only at very special conditions (CO-CO2 atmosphere, 553 K) [40], quite different from these used in this work, so that we can exclude this possibility. The Pd-C solid solution, if formed, could exhibit behaviour like this reported here (lattice expansion ca. 2.8%, long term stability in air) [35-39]. There are, however, strong arguments against it. First of all, we did not observed the lattice expansion in Pd black treated at the same conditions as Pd/CeO~ sample, cf. Table 1, as could be expected if hydrocarbon emission from the apparatus itself would occur [35,36]. Secondly, the Pd-C solution is known to decompose in hydrogen at 400-460 K [35-37], and thus could not survive our HTR treatment. Thirdly, the Pd-C lattice parameter reported in literature (2.8%) is larger than observed in this work (2.1%). And finally, in previous works we have shown that HTR at 973 K of Pd supported on silica and alumina reduced the ability of Pd to constitute the supersaturated Pd-C solid solution [28,29]. It is worth mentioning that our HTR experiments were performed in flow condi- tions, with continuous removal of water vapour, which favours the oxide reduction and Pd-Ce alloying. Another effect that could account for Pd lattice expansion is its straining due to epitaxial deposition on CeO2. It is very likely for small (few nm) Pd particles, but seems impossible for 50 nm particles (average particle size estimated from XRD -- see Table 2). ED and HRTEM results from even larger particle (Fig. 13) also confirm the Pd lattice expansion. 4.3. Decoration of Pd particles Recent HRTEM observations revealed that reduction at temperatures 873 K or higher caused the decoration of Pd [15] or Rh [11] particles supported on ceria. In this work we showed that in Pd/CeO2 reduced at 1100 K islands of the crystalline CeO2 are formed on large Pd particles. On [112] oriented Pd we observed special epitaxial orientation of CeO2 islands such that CeO2 (111) fringes are parallel or rotated by 60° to Pd (111) fringes. Alexandrou and Nix [30] reported that upon annealing in UHV at 573-973 K ceria overlayers form an ordered structures on the Pd (111) surface. 4.4. Mechanism of CeO2 reduction Process of CeO2 reduction in hydrogen is quite complex. The reason is that in addition to a number of intermediate phases present the process itself depends 216 L. In the first stage, up to ca. 770 K surface reduction takes place, followed by bulk reduction at higher tempera- tures, which eventually leads to hexagonal Ce203 at around 1200 K [21]. Below 1200 K nonstoichiometric oxides are obtained with the crystal structure being the modifications of the original fluorite type structure of CeO2 [42,43]. It has been shown that the lattice parameter of the pseudo-cubic cell determined for these oxides increases with decreasing oxygen content from 0.541 to 0.556 nm [21,44,15]. Results presented in this work, as well as literature data [21,15] show that maximum lattice expansion of fluorite-like CeO2 amounts to ca. 2.8% and then transformation into new hexagonal lattice occurs. The transformation temperature is ca. 1170 K ([21,42], this work), though there are indications that the cubic C-Ce203 structure (a = 1.11 nm) may occur as an intermediate phase at about 1073 K [21,43]. Important is that despite prolonged reduction at 1180 K (this work) or even at 1273 K [21], we still have a coexistence of hexagonal and fluorite-like ceria. Reduction of high surface ceria in H2 is additionally complicated by a simultaneous decrease of its specific surface area [45]. Two processes are involved in this effect: elimination of the microporosity (i.e., collapse of voids between CeO2 crystallites) as the first step and then, above 800 K, growth of the crystallites [45]. It appears, however, that for reduction temperatures above 873 K initial surface area has no significant influence on the phase transformations of ceria [21]. We can roughly estimate changes of the surface area of ceria in our Pd/ceria sample using average crystallite size obtained from XRD and TEM. For the initial sample (crystallite size 5.2 nm) we obtain surface area 160 m2/g taking ceria density 7.14 g/cm3 and assuming identical cubic crystallites not touching each other. This rather unrealistic assumption is, however, reasonably well fulfilled for high surface cerias treated at low temperatures [45]. At higher temperatures there is rapid decrease in the surface area due to collapse of voids between crystallites and growth of crystallite size. Obviously XRD can detect only the latter effect, but TEM (cf. Fig. 5) clearly shows that to some extent at 573 K, but quite extensively at 773 K, ceria crystallites undergo sintering. At 973 K, there is practically no empty space between ceria crystallites, so that specific surface area (30 m2/g) calculated from XRD data evidently overesti- mates the true exposed surface (i.e., available for adsorption) (cf. [45]). In our opinion the effect of sintering described above on ceria reduction in H2 can be described as follows. At 473 K surface reduction of ceria begins and at 620-670 K all cerium ions at a surface are reduced to 3 + [21]. For long reduction times, when due to the sintering the total surface area of ceria decreases, a fraction of these Ce3+ ions must move to the bulk since in hydrogen atmosphere there is no possibility to reoxidise them. The presence of Ce3+ ions (i.e., also oxygen vacancies) in ceria lattice further facilitates its sintering [46] and thus the process is auto-catalytic. It could possibly account for L. Kcpihski, M. In the presence of Pd complete surface reduction of ceria occurs already at room temperature [47] and therefore the effect described above is even more pronounced. This could explain rather high, if compared with literature [45], growth of ceria crystallite sizes in our sample during reduction at 573 and 773 K. An abrupt increase in ceria crystallite size at 973 K which coincides with its phase transformation to a new 'expanded' cubic structure must include extensive mobility of ceria species. It could possibly accelerate pits formation (discussed below) and facilitate Pd-ceria interaction (Pd-Ce alloy formation and Pd decoration). In an oxidising atmosphere, oxygen deficient fluorite-like CeOX exhibiting the expanded lattice parameter reoxidises very quickly even at room temperature to nearly stoichiometric CeOe [21,44,15]. However, the presence of additives as e.g. C1 ions from the metal precursor can stabilise the expanded CeO2 lattice [15]. The hexagonal Ce203 phase also reoxidises in air to fluorite like CeO2 but with much lower rate (Fig. 3, [21]). Our TEM results shine some light onto the process of CeO2-Ce203 transformation. It appears that the hexagonal phase grows on the fluorite CeO2 in an ordered manner. coredata.dc:description: The effect of high temperature reduction (HTR) in hydrogen (up to 1180 K) on the microstructure of 9 wt.-% Pd CeO 2 catalyst was studied by HRTEM and XRD methods. Reduction of the catalyst at or above 973 K caused severe recrystallization of CeO2 and Pd with simultaneous strong interaction between the two components appearing as three phenomena: epitaxial growth of small Pd particles on CeO2 (most frequently with [111]Pd∥[111]CeO2); decoration of large Pd particles with ordered CeO2 overlayer and expansion of the lattice parameter of Pd (by 2.1%). The origin of the Pd lattice expansion is discussed and diffusion of Ce species into the Pd lattice seems to be the most probable one. HTR caused also phase transformations in the ceria support. At 973 K and 1100 K, whole CeO2 was transformed into oxygen deficient CeO x phase exhibiting the same or similar structure but with expanded lattice parameter (by 2.8%). At 1180 K most ceria was transformed into hexagonal A-Ce2 3. The CeO x phase appeared to be stable in hydrogen and in vacuum at room temperature, but upon exposure to air at room temperature it rapidly reoxidised to CeO2. Ce2O3 also reoxidised to CeO2 but much slower. Another consequence of HTR at or above 773 K was formation of pits in CeO2 crystallites, mainly on (112)-type crystal faces. The pits (1–10 nm) exhibited well defined walls parallel to CeO2 lattice fringes and they could possibly constitute nucleation sites for strongly bonded, epitaxial oriented Pd particles.
coredata.dc:title: Microstructure of Pd CeO 2 catalyst: Effect of high temperature reduction in hydrogen
